Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for the "50 Years of the Seismology of the Sun and Stars" Workshop; Sunspot, New Mexico; May 6-10, 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Scientific Organizing Committee convening a workshop at the National Solar Observatory (NSO) in Sunspot, NM, from May 6 to May 10, 2013. The workshop is entitled, "50 Years of the Seismology of the Sun and Stars," and it is important to note that the year 2013 is an important milestone in helioseismology, being the 50th anniversary year of the discovery of the 5-minute solar oscillation.

This NSO workshop will bring together solar and stellar seismologists, theorists, and observers on the occasion of completing 50 years of helioseismic investigations, in order to discuss recent scientific advances and plan for future research. The workshop will be structured to include invited talks on various key topics, to be followed by contributed talks, discussions, and posters.

The Organizers plan to publish proceedings of the workshop within a time frame of six months. These proceedings will represent an historical overview of the scientific results in helioseismology over the last 50 years. This document's purpose is to help young new researchers understand the historical development of the field, as well as to aid in planning future instrumentation and the theoretical interpretation of future observations. Based on NSO's past experience with this kind of workshop, the Organizers expect the participation of a large number of graduate students, women, and underrepresented minorities, all of whom will be recruited to attend.

The committee members are planning for this event to be limited to about 60 to 70 attendees and they intend use this NSF award to provide partial travel support for 10-14 participants representing the categories of invited speakers, young researchers, and under-represented researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A workshop on the theme of "Fifty Years of Seismology of the Sun and Stars" was organized by the National Solar Observatory in Tucson, AZ during 6-10 May 2013. The workshop offered a forum (i) to take stock of what has been learned about the Sun's interior structure and dynamics in the last fifty years, (ii) to discuss what has been missed and (iii) to deliberate on upcoming paths of research to answer some of the remaining scientific questions.  The workshop was attended by 83 participants from various countries spanning across 5 continents and included solar and stellar seismologists, observers and theoreticians. Some of the discoverers of the 5-minute oscillations and early theoretical interpreters also attended the meeting and described the initial excitement of a new field. 

The meeting started with an historical overview of the beginnings of helioseismology dating back to the early 1960s and was presented by the scientists who made the pioneering observations and the critical theoretical breakthroughs.  The meeting was greatly enlivened by the mix of participants, which included some of the founders of the field, many current practitioners and the generation of young scientists. The scientific sessions featured invited and contributed talks as well as poster sessions and provided networking opportunities among the participants.

In much the same manner as geophysicists study the internal properties of the Earth from seismic events, the study of the oscillations of the Sun, known as "helioseismology," is the only diagnostic tool to probe the invisible interior structure and dynamics of the Sun. These oscillations, which manifest themselves as Doppler shifts on the solar surface vibrate with a period centered around 5 minutes, were discovered in the early 1960s. The accurate measurements of oscillation frequencies provide stringent constraints on the internal properties of the Sun and distant stars. The continuing efforts in helioseismology will help to reveal the nature and strength of the magnetic field present in the solar interior and will also help in establishing the causes that drive the solar and stellar cycles.

A major highlight was the panel discussion on the future directions in helioseismology. The discussions emphasized the coordinated team efforts to examine and exploit the scientific benefits of long-term continuous helioseismic observations.  The developments of a new ground-based, multi-purpose solar synoptic observing network with capabilities of measuring solar oscillations in multi-wavelength and a multi-viewpoint solar space mission were also advocated.

The final outcome of the workshop is the publication of the proceedings in the Astronomical Society of the Pacific Conference Series (Volume 478).  This contains a total of 52 papers which captures the scientific highlights of the meeting and will serve as a reference book for professionals with a strong interest in modern developments in helioseismology.
